FELBINAC

Indications and doses

Relief of pain in musculoskeletal conditions, Treatment in knee or hand osteoarthritis (adjunct),

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply 2–4 times a day, therapy should be reviewed after 14 days; maximum 25 g per day.

Drug action

Felbinac is an active metabolite of the NSAID fenbufen.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Patient packs for topical preparations carry a warning to avoid during pregnancy.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

With systemic use

Use with caution; there is an increased risk of gastro-intestinal bleeding and fluid retention.

Avoid in severe liver disease.

Advice regarding renal impairment

With systemic use

The lowest effective dose should be used for the shortest possible duration.

With systemic use

Avoid if possible or use with caution.

With topical use

Deterioration in renal function has also been reported after topical use.

Contra indications

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Photosensitivity,

Specific side effects

rare: alveolitis, aseptic meningitis (patients with connective-tissue disorders such as systemic lupus erythematosus may be especially susceptible), hepatic damage, interstitial fibrosis associated with NSAIDs can lead to renal failure, pancreatitis, papillary necrosis associated with NSAIDs can lead to renal failure, pulmonary eosinophilia, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, visual disturbances,

notKnown: angioedema, blood disorders, bronchospasm, colitis (induction of or exacerbation of), Crohn’s disease (induction of or exacerbation of), depression, diarrhoea, dizziness, drowsiness, fluid retention (rarely precipitating congestive heart failure), gastro-intestinal bleeding, gastro-intestinal discomfort, gastro-intestinal disturbances, gastro-intestinal ulceration, haematuria, headache, hearing disturbances, hypersensitivity reactions, insomnia, nausea, nervousness, raised blood pressure, renal failure (especially in patients with pre-existing renal impairment), tinnitus, vertigo, rash (discontinue use if develops),

Serious side-effects

For information about cardiovascular and gastro-intestinal side-effects, and a possible exacerbation of symptoms in asthma, see Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

With topical use

Topical application of large amounts can result in systemic effects, including hypersensitivity and asthma (renal disease has also been reported).

Directions for administration

With topical use

For topical preparations, apply with gentle massage only.

Advice for patients and carers

For topical preparations patients and carers should be advised to wash hands immediately after use.

Photosensitivity

Patients should be advised against excessive exposure to sunlight of area treated in order to avoid possibility of photosensitivity.

Cautions regarding administration

  • With systemic use: allergic disorders
  • With systemic use: cardiac impairment (NSAIDs may impair renal function)
  • With systemic use: cerebrovascular disease
  • With systemic use: coagulation defects
  • With systemic use: connective-tissue disorders
  • With systemic use: Crohn’s disease (may be exacerbated)
  • With systemic use: elderly (risk of serious side-effects and fatalities)
  • With systemic use: heart failure
  • With systemic use: ischaemic heart disease
  • With systemic use: peripheral arterial disease
  • With systemic use: risk factors for cardiovascular events
  • With systemic use: ulcerative colitis (may be exacerbated)
  • With systemic use: uncontrolled hypertension
  • With topical use: avoid contact with eyes
  • With topical use: avoid contact with inflamed or broken skin
  • With topical use: avoid contact with mucous membranes
  • With topical use: not for use with occlusive dressings
  • With topical use: topical application of large amounts can result in systemic effects, including hypersensitivity and asthma (renal disease has also been reported)

Advice regarding conception and contraception

With systemic use

Caution—long-term use of some NSAIDs is associated with reduced female fertility, which is reversible on stopping treatment.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Caution—topical preparations not generally suitable for children.

Advice regarding allergies and cross sensitivities

Contraindicated in patients with a history of hypersensitivity to aspirin or any other NSAID—which includes those in whom attacks of asthma, angioedema, urticaria or rhinitis have been precipitated by aspirin or any other NSAID.

Prepared medicinal forms of FELBINAC

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Foam
Gel
